body_html:
You can install stuff from the shell using apt-get install (including
editors). If you want this to be done more persistently you can derive your
own sub dockerfile that is derived from the tensorflow one (in fact
tensorflow is derived from the ubuntu image one).

-A

On Mon, Aug 22, 2016 at 2:59 PM Roboball notifications@github.com wrote:

thank you. just one final question. Can I use some comfortable editor like
spyder from anaconda?? or do I have to stick to bash in cmd prompt?

finally this code line worked for me:
docker run -it b.gcr.io/tensorflow/tensorflow:latest-devel``
http://b.gcr.io/tensorflow/tensorflow:latest-devel
for reference:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/35582875/unable-to-start-tensorflow-within-docker-on-windows

—

tensorflow is derived from the ubuntu image one).

body:
You can install stuff from the shell using apt-get install (including
editors). If you want this to be done more persistently you can derive your
own sub dockerfile that is derived from the tensorflow one (in fact
tensorflow is derived from the ubuntu image one).

-A

On Mon, Aug 22, 2016 at 2:59 PM Roboball notifications@github.com wrote:

> thank you. just one final question. Can I use some comfortable editor like
> spyder from anaconda?? or do I have to stick to bash in cmd prompt?
> 
> finally this code line worked for me:
> docker run -it b.gcr.io/tensorflow/tensorflow:latest-devel``
> http://b.gcr.io/tensorflow/tensorflow:latest-devel
> for reference:
> 
> http://stackoverflow.com/questions/35582875/unable-to-start-tensorflow-within-docker-on-windows
>
